intro: Cephaelis guarupana, commonly known as Brazilian flame flower, is a flowering plant native to the tropical regions of South America. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family, which includes over 13,000 species of flowering plants. The plant is characterized by its striking, tubular flowers that range in color from red to orange, often with contrasting white or yellow markings. It typically grows as an upright shrub, reaching heights of up to 2 meters, and thrives in humid, shaded environments. The leaves are usually opposite, ovate, and have a leathery texture, while the flowers are often visited by hummingbirds and other pollinators.
